awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Feasibility and Fundamentals of Femtosecond-Laser Shock Peening Without Protective Coating in Air Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Laser induced, localized shock waves can generate compressive stresses in a metal's surface that improve the hardness and fatigue of the part without altering its bulk material properties. This process, nanosecond laser shock peening, requires a protective coating to combat the heat affect zone, and a confining medium to promote the shock waves. The research will investigate the ability of a femtosecond laser shock peening process, which has higher energy density, to achieve the same result without the need for the protective coating and confinement layer. Eliminating the coating and confinement layer will significantly reduce setup complexity and manufacturing costs. Knowledge gained on the fundamental physical mechanisms occurring during femtosecond laser peening will be leveraged to realize a higher resolution process capable of processing a broader range of materials than currently possible by nanosecond laser peening. This advanced manufacturing capability will contribute to the competitiveness of the US by finding application in the development of progressive precision instrumentation, 3D-printing technologies, biomedical implants, and micro-mechanical systems. In addition to providing graduate students with advanced manufacturing expertise, the research results will be integrated into both course modules and educational outreach activities aimed at underrepresented minorities to further encourage more qualified people into the manufacturing work force. 

The research objective is to understand the fundamental mechanisms and limitations of femtosecond laser shock peening without a protective coating in an air environment. To achieve this both process related non-equilibrium electron dynamics, and super-high strain-rate deformation mechanisms will be investigated. A unique in-situ measurement method will be used to capture the plasma dynamics occurring during femtosecond laser shock peening of stainless steel 304 and aluminum 6061 samples. The microstructure evolution will be characterized to study the deformation dynamics under ultrahigh pressure and stain rate, while the surface morphology, residual stress, surface hardness, and fatigue will be measured to test the effectiveness of the process. Hybrid numerical models, validated by experiments, will be utilized to further understand the underlying mechanisms. A Fokker-Planck model will focus on revealing non-equilibrium electron dynamics. Outputs from this model will be incorporated into a hydrodynamic model to predict the resultant plasma formation and shock wave generation. The shock wave information will be integrated into a finite element model to assist in predicting the deformation process of metals subjected to super-high strain-rate impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Metal parts in machinery facing harsh conditions can deteriorate, leading to wear and fatigue. Laser shock peening (LSP) can strengthen metal surfaces by using rapid laser pulses to produce shock waves, enhancing performance and durability. Traditional nanosecond laser shock peening (ns-LSP) requires a confining medium like water or glass, and a protective coating, adding complexity and cost. This project demonstrates femtosecond laser shock peening (fs-LSP) can overcome these barriers. Moreover, it integrates numerical modeling and experiments to establish a knowledge base for fs-LSP by understanding fs laser-induced shock waves and their impact on material microstructures and mechanical properties.

Outcomes:

A fs-LSP platform, among the earliest in North America, has been developed. It operates seamlessly in ambient air, eliminating the need for coatings or confining media. The processing speed of this technique could potentially surpass ns-LSP and other severe plastic deformation processes by over 10,000 times.

A comprehensive model integrating a hydrodynamic model and a two-temperature model (TTM) was developed. It accurately captures the laser-induced shock waves during fs-LSP, considering essential physics like ultrafast laser absorption, non-equilibrium electron-phonon coupling, phase change, ablation, and plasma evolution.

A Fokker-Planck (FP) model was built to effectively account for non-equilibrium electron dynamics during fs-LSP.

A finite element model was constructed to calculate material deformation and residual stress during LSP.

The results of this project have yielded 9 journal articles, 3 peer-reviewed conference articles, 8 conference oral presentations including 2 invited talks, 1 upcoming PhD dissertation (December 2023), and 2 master theses associated with the work at Clemson University (CU). The project's outcomes garnered prestigious recognition, receiving the Best Paper Award at the ASME 2020 International Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference and the Outstanding Young Manufacturing Engineer Award from the Society of Manufacturing Engineers for the PI. Additionally, undergraduate students affiliated with the project were honored with the Carl Donner Nelson Jr. Memorial Award and the Excellence in Engineering Award.

Major findings:

The effects of confining medium and protective coating on the peening results were studied. It was found that fs-LSP can significantly enhance surface hardness by over 45% without any confining medium and protective coating due to its extremely high laser-induced shock waves. The study, for the first time, affirms that fs-LSP eliminates the need for a confining medium and protective coating. It has great potential to replace ns-LSP due to its much higher flexibility, lower cost, simpler procedure, and higher throughput.

During fs-LSP, super intense laser-induced shock waves (exceeding 800 GPa) were observed near the material surface, over ten times more powerful than any other severe plastic deformation technique. This leads to an effective hardness improvement and extensive nanoscale grain refinement near the surface, associated with high-density stacking and twinning faults. However, the shock wave duration is extremely short, lasting only hundreds of nanoseconds. This leads to a rapid decay of shock wave intensity by one order within tens of microns, yielding a hardness improvement depth of only tens of microns, notably shallower than ns-LSP (~ mm). Nanograins were limited to a thin surface layer (~ 1 micron), with moderate grain refinement observed beyond this range.

Fs-LSP can cause non-equilibrium electron dynamics, rendering classical diffusion theory inaccurate. Using FP simulation, it was found classical theory underestimates electron temperature at low laser intensities and overestimates it at high intensities. An empirical heat flux limiter, derived from FP simulation, effectively corrects this, marking a significant advancement in fs-LSP and promising improved manufacturing across industries.

The effect of fs-LSP on the fatigue life of additive-manufactured alloys was studied. It was found that fs-LSP has little impact on low cycle fatigue life but significantly reduces the scatter. This suggests that fs-LSP could offer more consistent fatigue life in additive manufacturing, aiding certification and bolstering confidence in material performance.

Workforce development:

At CU, significant contributions have been made through the engagement of students in this project. One PhD student and two master's students, one of whom was female, were extensively trained and actively participated. Additionally, another PhD student and 19 undergraduate students, including 7 from underrepresented groups, were also integral to the research efforts. They were trained in laser-matter interaction, numerical modeling, and experimental skills. Two PhD students had internships at OpTek Systems in Fall 2020. Both master's students have graduated and started their engineering careers in Fidelis and General Electric, respectively.

The PI has integrated the results of this project into his graduate-level course, ME8760 Laser-based Manufacturing and Materials Processing, which has been designated as a core component in the newly established Mechanical Engineering Certificate in Advanced Manufacturing Processes.

The PI has been actively involved with various outreach activities, such as STEM ALL IN and CAREER events, to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion within STEM disciplines.


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Xin Zhao
